If secure transfer to storage account is not enabled, then the request from any insecure connections to these storage accounts will also be accepted. Thus, the storage data will always be vulnerable to several network layer attacks such as man-in-the-middle, eavesdropping, and session-hijacking.
Enabling secure transfer to storage accounts will reject all the connections made over http.

An Azure storage account contains data objects such as files, blobs, queues, tables, and disks. It provides a unique namespace for the storage data that is accessible from anywhere in the world over http or https. All data stored within these storage accounts should be secure, scalable, durable, and highly available. It is recommended to enable secure transfer to the storage accounts as it will ensure that the requests only from secure connections (https) will be accepted and any request originating from an insecure connection will be rejected. Also, use of secure transfer will protect the storage data from any kind of network layer attacks, such as man-in-the-middle, eavesdropping, and session-hijacking.
(Related policy: Secure transfer to storage accounts should be enabled)

If the access to the Azure storage account is not restricted using firewall and virtual network configurations, then any attacker will be able to access these storage accounts without getting detected, through the use of malicious IP addresses or public endpoints.

If the access to Azure storage account is restricted by configuring virtual network and firewall, then any incoming request other than the one originating from any service that is operating within an Azure virtual network or an allowed IP address, will be blocked.

An Azure storage account contains data objects such as files, blobs, queues, tables, and disks. Configuring firewalls and virtual networks for a storage account will enable us to secure and control the level of access to these storage accounts by the applications. It will ensure that the requests originating from specified IP addresses, IP ranges or from a list of subnets in an Azure virtual network are able to access the storage account. It will also help us in controlling the access for the public endpoints(accessible through the internet) of the storage accounts.
(Related policy: Audit unrestricted network access to storage accounts)

If the Microsoft-managed key is used instead of a customer-managed key for encrypting the storage account, then the key's creation, storage, rotation, and lifecycle will all be managed by Microsoft. This key management policy may not be in adherence to the global/state regulatory requirements. Additionally, the Microsoft-managed keys does not provide audit logs as well as fine grained controls over the key access, thereby any misuse of this key may go unnoticed.

Remediation of this control will ensure that customer-managed keys are used for encrypting the storage accounts, but both the Key-Vault and the key used for encryption must not get deleted or expired, as this will make the storage account inaccessible.

Storage account's content, by default, is encrypted by the Microsoft-managed keys (transparent to the application and are managed by Microsoft). In order to enhance the security, an additional layer of encryption should be applied using a customer-managed key (created by a customer and stored in the key vault or generated using the Azure key vault's APIs). Customer-managed keys enables a customer to encrypt the data with an Azure Key Vault key that is created and owned by them. Also, the customer has full control and responsibility for the key lifecycle, including rotation and management. Hence, it is recommended to use customer-managed keys to encrypt the storage account.
(Related policy: Storage accounts should use customer-managed key (CMK) for encryption)

If access to storage account is not restricted by the virtual network rules, then any attacker will be able to gain access to the data present in the storage account from malicious IP addresses or domains without getting detected. Along with this, the storage account will also be susceptible to other network attacks like DDoS, Eavesdropping, etc.

If the access to the storage accounts is restricted by configuring the virtual network rules, then any incoming request other than the one originating from any service that is operating within an Azure virtual network or an allowed IP address, will be blocked. Hence, it must be exercised cautiously so that all the trusted resources and services are able to access the storage account.

A storage account by default accepts connections over the internet from hosts on any network. To protect the storage account from potential threats, it must be ensured that access is restricted to only specific public IP addresses or address ranges by configuring the virtual network rules of the storage account.
(Related policy: Storage accounts should restrict network access using virtual network rules)

Without enabling diagnostic logs in virtual machine scale set, one will not be able to diagnose actions and operations responsible for any security incidents within virtual machine scale set, which could have been detected with the help of generated logs.
Remediating this control enables logging for virtual machine scale set, however those logs cannot be sent to Log Analytics workspace for analysis and only sends logs to Azure storage and Event Hubs.

Azure virtual machine scale sets let you create and manage a group of load balanced virtual machines. The Diagnostic Logs are logs emitted by a resource and provide rich and frequent insights into the operations of that resource. The virtual machine scale set uses the data of the diagnostic logs on the virtual machines for autoscaling purpose. These logs enables you to recreate activity trails for investigation purposes. This is useful when a security incident occurs, or your network is compromised. Therefore, it is recommended to enable diagnostic logs for virtual machine scale set.
(Related policy: Diagnostic logs in Virtual Machine Scale Sets should be enabled)

Without resolving endpoint health issues, the installed endpoint protection won't function properly and it's provided protection for endpoints will be faulty. This way any attacker will still be able to misuse and exploit endpoint deployments and because it has access to both the central server and the outside world, any flaw or gap in it's security will increase the likelihood of loss of crucial data from the server.
Remediating this control resolves endpoint health issues, which will not have any impact.

Endpoint protection systems (like Antimalware for Azure) provides real-time protection capability that helps identify and remove viruses, spyware, and other malicious software. It offers three ways to help protect your virtual machine scale set from malware and other potentially unwanted software which include Realtime Protection, Scanning Options and Detections. However, the health issues associated with it must be resolved in order to ensure that installed endpoint protection is fully functioning without any errors. Therefore, it is recommended to resolve endpoint protection health issues.   
(No related policy - dependent upon "Endpoint protection solution should be installed on virtual machine scale sets")

Without installing endpoint protection, the attack surface of virtual machine scale set is increased, as the endpoints have access to both the central server and the outside world making it more susceptible to various viruses and malicious softwares. Also, no alerts will be generated when known malicious or unwanted software tries to install itself or run on virtual machine scale set.
Remediating this control installs endpoint protection for virtual machine scale set, which will incur additional charges.

Installing endpoint protection systems (like Antimalware for Azure) provides for real-time protection capability that helps identify and remove viruses, spyware, and other malicious software. It offers three ways to help protect your virtual machine scale set from malware and other potentially unwanted software which include Realtime Protection, Scanning Options and Detections. Thus, it is recommended to install enpoint protection on your virtual machine scale set to keep it protected from commonly identifiable threats.
(Related policy: Endpoint protection solution should be installed on virtual machine scale sets)

Without installing Log Analytics agent, it will not be possible to collect logs and performance data from virtual machine scale sets and send it to a Log Analytics workspace to take advantage of features supported by Azure Monitor Logs such as log queries where the logs can be analyzed together using a sophisticated query language that's capable of quickly analyzing millions of records, which can bring out critical patterns (like resource usage insights, protocol failures, network outages etc) in your monitoring data with the help of which the organisation can solve detected problems as quickly as possible or prevent them before they happen.

Remediating this control installs Log Analytics agent, which will not have any impact, however the collected data cannot be sent to the Azure Monitor Metrics, Azure Storage, or Azure Event Hubs. Also, it is difficult to configure unique monitoring definitions for individual agents and manage individual scale set configurations, thus it's implementation must be exercised with caution.

The Log Analytics agent collects monitoring data from the guest operating system and workloads of virtual machines in Azure, other cloud providers, and on-premises. It sends data to a Log Analytics workspace. The Log Analytics agent is the same agent used by System Center Operations Manager, and you can multihome agent computers to communicate with your management group and Azure Monitor simultaneously. Auto-deployment of the agent for Azure virtual machine scale sets cannot be configured, therefore log analytics agent should be deployed on virtual machine scale sets (including those used by Azure managed services such as Azure Kubernetes Service and Azure Service Fabric).

Without installing the system updates for the Windows and Linux virtual machine scale set, it will be vulnerable to many security loopholes, as outdated software is prone to malware infections. Also, plenty of bugs and issues that may have been patched will remain unfixed, thereby decreasing the user experience.
Remediating this control will install the latest system updates, which must be done with caution and it must be ensured that the existing functionalities don't get impacted.

System updates are necessary to maintain operational efficiency, overcome security issues, and reduce the risks of increased cyber security threats. Hence, it is recommended to install the system updates to keep your Windows and Linux virtual machine scale set up to date with latest security developments.
(Related policy: System updates on virtual machine scale sets should be installed)

Without the security configuration vulnerabilites being remediated, a number of operating system vulnerabilities that include data breaches, account takeovers or infecting with malwares and ransomwares, can compromise the operating system and cause loss of data.
Remediating this control removes the security configuration vulnerabilities, which must be done with caution and it must be ensured that the existing functionalities don't get impacted.

The operating system of the virtual machines are vulnerable to many cyber attacks. Azure Security Center analyzes daily the operating system of the virtual machines for configurations that could make them more vulnerable to cyber attacks. The Security Center service also recommends specific configuration changes that can be applied in order to address any found operating system vulnerabilities. Hence, these recommendations must be followed in order to remediate the vulnerabilites that the operating system is prone to. 
(Related policy: Vulnerabilities in security configuration on your virtual machine scale sets should be remediated)

If Azure Defender is not enabled for container registries (that stores and manages the container images for Azure deployments) then the Security Center will not be able to run the vulnerability scan and provide actionable recommendations and remediation guidelines to fix vulnerabilities for the images that are pushed to the registry, imported into the registry, or pulled within the last 30 days.

If Azure Defender is enabled for container registries, then additional charges will be incurred for the scan of each image that is immediately pushed into the registry or pulled within the last 30 days.

Azure Container Registry (ACR) is a managed, private docker registry service that stores and manages the container images for Azure deployments. Once Azure Defender for container registries is enabled, the Security Center will scan images that are pushed to the registry, imported into the registry, or pulled within the last 30 days. Incase a vulnerability is found, then it will be notified in the Security Center's dashboard along with the actionable recommendations, severity classification, and remediation guidance. But this feature of scanning vulnerabilities of the images will incur charges per image. To build secure containerized workloads, ensure the images that they're based on are free of known vulnerabilities using Azure Defender.
Important: Remediating this recommendation will result in charges for protecting the ACR registries. If we don't have any ACR registries in the subscription, no charges will be incurred. If we create any ACR registries on the subscription in the future, they will automatically be protected and charges will begin at that time.
(Related policy: Advanced threat protection should be enabled on Azure Container Registry registries)
If Azure Defender for kubernetes is not enabled, then attacks like resource hijacking can be carried out without generating any alert or getting detected, which may compromise container data.
If Azure Defender is enabled for kubernetes cluster to provide real-time threat protection, then additional charges will be incurred.

Azure Kubernetes Service (AKS) is an open-source software for deploying, managing and scaling containers that are used for building modern applications. Azure Defender for kubernetes should be enabled as it provides real-time threat protection of the kubernetes cluster(multi-containers) and generates alerts for suspicious activities. We can use this information to quickly remediate security issues and improve the security of our containers. 
Important: Remediating this recommendation will result in charges for protecting your AKS clusters. If you don't have any AKS clusters in this subscription, no charges will be incurred. If you create any AKS clusters on this subscription in the future, they will automatically be protected and charges will begin at that time.
(Related policy: Advanced threat protection should be enabled on Azure Kubernetes Service clusters)

If Azure Defender for App Service is not enabled, then attacks like SQL injection or cross-site scripting can go undetected and the attacker can access the App Service and the resources covered by it.
If Azure Defender is enabled for App Service and it's resources, then additional charges will be incurred.

Azure App Service is a fully managed web hosting service for building web apps, mobile back ends and RESTful APIs. Azure Defender for App Service uses cloud scaling to identify attacks targeting applications running over App Service. Attackers probe web applications to find and exploit weaknesses. Before being routed to specific environments, requests to applications running in Azure go through several gateways, where they're inspected and logged. This data is then used to identify exploits and attacks, and to learn new patterns that will be used later. By using the visibility that Azure has as a cloud provider, Security Center analyzes App Service internal logs to identify attack methodology on multiple targets and generate security recommendations based on its findings.
Important: Remediating this recommendation will result in charges for protecting your App Service plans. If there are no App Service plans in the subscription, no charges will be incurred. If we create any App Service plans on the subscription in the future, they will automatically be protected and charges will begin at that time.
(Related policy: Advanced threat protection should be enabled on Azure App Service plans)
If Azure Defender for servers is not enabled, then any attack like DDOS and brute force can break the servers without causing alerts or getting detected.
If Azure Defender is enabled for real-time threat protection to server, then additional charges will be incurred.

Azure Defender for servers provides real-time threat protection for the server workloads and generates hardening recommendations as well as alerts about suspicious activities. We can use this information to quickly remediate security issues and improve the security of our virtual machines.
Important: Remediating this recommendation will result in charges for protecting our virtual machines. If we don't have any virtual machines in the subscription, no charges will be incurred. If we create any virtual machines on the subscription in the future, they will automatically be protected and charges will begin at that time.
(Related policy: Advanced threat protection should be enabled on virtual machines)

If Azure Defender for SQL Database servers is not enabled then we will not be able to detect anomalous database access patterns and mitigate potential database vulnerabilities such as Azure SQL injection attacks.
If Azure Defender is enabled for protecting SQL Database servers, then additional charges will be incurred.

Azure Defender for SQL Database servers is a unified package that provides advanced SQL security capabilities. It includes functionality for surfacing and mitigating potential database vulnerabilities, detecting anomalous activities that could indicate a threat to the database, and discovering and classifying sensitive data.
Important: Remediating this recommendation will result in charges for protecting the Azure SQL Database servers. If we don't have any Azure SQL Database servers in the subscription, no charges will be incurred. If we create any Azure SQL Database servers on this subscription in the future, they will automatically be protected and charges will begin at that time.
(Related policy: Advanced data security should be enabled on Azure SQL Database servers)

If Azure Defender for SQL servers on machines is not enabled then we will not be able to detect and mitigate potential database vulnerabilities such as Azure SQL injection attacks and will not receive any alerts in case of a threat.
If Azure Defender is enabled for protecting SQL servers on machines, then additional charges will be incurred.

Azure Defender for SQL servers is a unified package that provides advanced SQL security capabilities. It includes functionality for surfacing and mitigating potential database vulnerabilities, detecting anomalous activities that could indicate a threat to the database, and discovering and classifying sensitive data. It will also provide alerts when there are suspicious database activities, potential vulnerabilities, or SQL injection attacks, and anomalous database access and query patterns.
Important: Remediating this recommendation will result in charges for protecting the SQL servers on machines. If we don't have any SQL servers on machines in the subscription, no charges will be incurred. If we create any SQL servers on machines on the subscription in the future, they will automatically be protected and charges will begin at that time. 
(Related policy: Advanced data security should be enabled on SQL servers on machines)
If Microsoft Defender is not enabled for Storage accounts, then any access from suspicious IPs, anomalous access patterns or any malware uploads to storage shall go undetected.
If Microsoft Defender is enabled for Storage accounts, then additional charges will be incurred.

Azure storage account contains all of the Azure Storage data objects: blobs, files, queues, tables, and disks. The storage account provides a unique namespace for the Azure Storage data that is accessible from anywhere in the world over HTTP or HTTPS. Azure Defender for Storage detects unusual and potentially harmful attempts to access or exploit the Storage accounts.
Important: Remediating this recommendation will result in charges for protecting your Azure Storage accounts. If we don't have any Azure Storage accounts in the subscription, no charges will be incurred. If we create any Azure Storage accounts on the subscription in the future, they will automatically be protected and charges will begin at that time.
(Related policy: Advanced threat protection should be enabled on Azure Storage accounts)

If more than three owners are assigned to a subscription, then there will be an increased probability of an owner account getting compromised and an increased attack surface, thereby giving owner privileges to an attacker, with which breaking changes can be made.
If there is a business requirement to have more than three owners to a subscription, then the remediation of this control should not be carried out.

Subscription owners are the users who have full access to all the resources in the subscription, including the right to delegate access to others. If more than three subscription owners are designated to a subscription then it will increase the chances of a compromised owner's account being used to gain access to the subscription and hence lead to a potential breach of security. It is recommended to keep a maximum of three owners to a subscription and monitor the number of owners via Azure Security Center to enforce this best practice.
(Related policy: A maximum of 3 owners should be designated for your subscription)

If Microsoft Defender for Key Vault is not enabled then you will not be able to detect unusual and potentially harmful access attempts that could lead to the Key Vault accounts being exploited, which could lead to the loss of confidential data.
If Microsoft Defender is enabled for Azure Key Vault accounts, then additional charges will be incurred.

Azure Key Vault is a cloud service that safeguards encryption keys and secrets like certificates, connection strings, and passwords. Enabling Azure Defender for Key Vault will provide advanced threat protection and add an additional layer of security intelligence. It will detect unusual and potentially harmful attempts to access or exploit Key Vault accounts. If an anomalous activity occurs then Azure Defender will send alerts via email to relevant members of the organization.
Important: Remediating this recommendation will result in charges for protecting your Azure Key Vaults. If we don't have any Azure Key Vaults in the subscription, no charges will be incurred. If we create any Azure Key Vault on the subscription in the future, they will automatically be protected and charges will begin at that time.
(Related policy: Advanced threat protection should be enabled on Azure Key Vault vaults)

If deprecated account is not removed and is present in any role on the subscription, then any attacker can target these accounts for accessing the applications that are still allowing access to them without getting detected.
If there is no requirement of deprecated accounts in the future, then they can be removed without any impact.

Deprecated accounts are the user accounts that have been blocked from signing in, and should be removed from the subscriptions. These accounts can be targets for attackers looking to find ways to access the data without being noticed. Therefore these accounts should be removed from the subscriptions to enable access to only current users.
(Related policy: Deprecated accounts should be removed from your subscription)

If deprecated account with owner permissions is not removed and is present in any role on the subscription, then an attacker can misuse it for accessing data, view sensitive information and edit the data, all without getting detected.
If there is no requirement of deprecated accounts with owner permissions in the future, then they can be removed without any impact.

(Related policy: Deprecated accounts with owner permissions should be removed from your subscription)

If external accounts with owner permissions are not removed from the subscription, then an attacker or an unauthorized user can gain access to the account from outside the domain, thus increasing the attack surface. With owner permissions, the attacker will be able to view sensitive data without being noticed (as these accounts are not managed or monitored by the organization) and put confidentiality of the account at risk, assign roles to the malicious accounts or manipulate the data present in the account making it unavailable for use.

If any of the external account is being used by subscriptions, then removing it will revoke its permissions. So, if there is a business requirement to allow an external account to use subscriptions then we should not remove it.

External accounts in Azure AD are accounts having different domain names than the one which is being used in corporate identities (such as Azure AD B2B collaboration, Microsoft Accounts, etc.). Usually, these accounts are not managed or monitored by the organization and can be targets for attackers looking to find ways to access the data without being noticed. External accounts with owner privileges should be removed from the subscription in order to prevent unmonitored access.
(Related policy: External accounts with owner permissions should be removed from your subscription)

If external accounts with read permissions are not removed from the subscription, then an attacker or an unauthorized user can gain access to the account from outside the domain, thus increasing the attack surface. With read permissions, the intruder will be able to view sensitive data without being noticed (as these accounts are not managed or monitored by the organization) and hence put the confidentiality of the data at risk.

External accounts with read privileges should be removed from the subscription in order to prevent unmonitored access.

If external accounts with write permissions are not removed from the subscription, then an attacker or an unauthorized user can gain access to the account from outside the domain, thus increasing the attack surface. With write permissions, the intruder will be able to view sensitive data without being noticed (as these accounts are not managed or monitored by the organization) and put confidentiality of the data at risk, as well as manipulate the data making it unavailable for use.

External accounts with write privileges should be removed from the subscription in order to prevent unmonitored access.
(Related policy: External accounts with write permissions should be removed from your subscription)

If MFA is not enabled on accounts with owner permission, then it will be relatively easier for an attacker or an unauthorized user to gain access to the account and perform malicious activity such as assigning roles to the malicious accounts, after having to bypass only a single layer of authentication. The intruder will be able to view the sensitive data and put the confidentiality of the data at risk, as well as manipulate the data, making it unavailable for use.
Enabling MFA for accounts with owner permission will not have any impact.

Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) is a process where a user is prompted during the sign-in process for an additional form of identification, such as to enter a code on the cellphone or to provide a fingerprint scan. Enabling Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) for all subscription accounts with owner privileges will prevent the breach of accounts or resources present in the subscription.
(Related policy: MFA should be enabled on accounts with owner permissions on your subscription)

If MFA is not enabled on accounts with read permission, then it will be relatively easier for an attacker or an unauthorized user to gain access to the account, after having to bypass only a single layer of authentication. The attacker will be able to view the sensitive data thereby putting the confidentiality of the data at risk.
Enabling MFA for accounts with read permission will not have any impact.

Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) is a process where a user is prompted during the sign-in process for an additional form of identification, such as to enter a code on the cellphone or to provide a fingerprint scan. Enable Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) for all subscription accounts with read privileges to prevent a breach of accounts or resources.
(Related policy: MFA should be enabled on accounts with read permissions on your subscription)

If MFA is not enabled on accounts with write permission, then it will be relatively easier for an attacker or an unauthorized user to gain access to the account, after having to bypass only a single layer of authentication. The attacker will be able to view the sensitive data and put the confidentiality of the data at risk, as well as manipulate the data, making it unavailable for use.
Enabling MFA for accounts with write permission will not have any impact.

Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) is a process where a user is prompted during the sign-in process for an additional form of identification, such as to enter a code on the cellphone or to provide a fingerprint scan. Enable Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) for all subscription accounts with write privileges to prevent a breach of accounts or resources.
(Related policy: MFA should be enabled on accounts with write permissions on your subscription)

If a subscription does not have more than one owner then it would become difficult to recover the account in case of an account lockout or compromise. Hence, having multiple users with owner role will ensure business continuity.

Assigning more than one subscription owner will not have any impact, but the privileges must be assigned with precaution as the assignee will have full access to all resources in the subscription, including the right to delegate access to others. It must be ensured that the monitoring of these accounts is more extensive.

Assigning an owner role to a user gives administrative access of the subscription to that user. It also gives the user full access to all resources in the subscription, including the right to delegate access to others. Hence it is recommended to designate more than one subscription owner in order to have multiple administrators, so that the potential for breach by a compromised owner is reduced.
(Related policy: There should be more than one owner assigned to your subscription)

If security contact details are not configured for the subscription then the security center will not send a notification email in case of a potential security breach, even when that anomaly is detected and recorded on the portal.

Remediation of this control will configure the security contact email addresses of the users to whom the notifications will be sent in case of a security breach, therefore it is recommended to add email address of the user/team from the right department who can take action on this notification email.

Security alerts should reach the right people in the organization, hence security contact details should be configured so that email notifications are sent from the Security Center to the relevant people in the organization in case of a potential security breach in one of the subscriptions.
(Related policy: Subscriptions should have a contact email address for security issues)
If auto provisioning of Log Analytics agent is not enabled on the subscription and it is also not installed manually post VM provisioning, it may lead to security issues within the VM go unnoticed.
Remediation of this control will automatically install Log Analytics agent on the virtual machines which will start logging data to Log Analytics Workspace resulting into the cost increase.

To monitor for security vulnerabilities and threats, Azure Security Center collects security data and events from the Azure virtual machines. Data is collected by the Log Analytics agent, formerly known as the Microsoft Monitoring Agent (MMA), which reads various security related configurations and event logs from the machine and copies the data (including crash dump files) to the Log Analytics workspace for analysis. The data sent for analysis is required to provide visibility into missing updates, misconfigured operating system (OS) security settings, endpoint protection settings, and health and threat detections. When the automatic provisioning of the monitoring agent is turned on, the Azure Security Center installs the MMA on all the existing supported Azure virtual machines, plus on any new ones created later.
(Related policy: Auto provisioning of the Log Analytics agent should be enabled on your subscription)

In absence of email notifications for high severity issues, a user or a security team would be required to visit the security center for monitoring the security incidents which may increase the turnaround time thus allowing a malicious user ample time to exploit the underlying issue.
Remediation of this control will not have any impact, also relevant users will be notified via email in case of a high severity security alert.

Enabling email notifications for high severity alerts ensures that in case of a potential security breach in one of the subscriptions, alerts will be sent via email to the relevant users of the organization, thereby helping the users to take necessary actions and mitigate the risk.
(Related policy: Email notification for high severity alerts should be enabled)
Without enabling email notifications to subscription owners for high severity alerts, the owner of the subscription will not get notified via email in case of a potential security breach.
Remediation of this control will not have any impact, also the subscription owner will be notified via email in case of a high severity security alert.

Enabling email notifications for subscription owners ensures that they receive security alert emails for important alert notifications, become aware of the security issues identified, and take necessary actions within the required time frame to mitigate the risk.
(Related policy: Email notification to subscription owner for high severity alerts should be enabled)

Network Watcher is a regional service that enables you to monitor and diagnose conditions at a network scenario level in, to, and from Azure. Scenario level monitoring enables you to diagnose problems at an end to end network level view. Network diagnostic and visualization tools available with Network Watcher help you understand, diagnose, and gain insights to your network in Azure.

Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA) should be enabled for all subscription accounts with read privileges to prevent a breach of accounts or resources.

If the service-managed key is used instead of a customer-managed key for encrypting the container registry, then the key's creation, storage, rotation, and lifecycle will all be managed by Microsoft. Thereby, the organization would lose control over the data, making it easily decryptable by a third-party service provider. Hence, it is recommended to use the customer-managed key for the encryption of the container registry's data as a best security practice.

Custumer-managed keys can only be enabled at the time of the creation of container registry. Once the customer-managed key is enabled for a container registry, it cannot be disabled. Also, content trust (enabling pushing and pulling of signed images) is not supported in a container registry encrypted with a customer-managed key.

Azure container registry's content(images and other artifacts), by default, is encrypted by the service-managed keys (transparent to the application and are managed by Microsoft). Inorder to enhance the security, an additional layer of encryption should be applied using a customer-managed key (created by a customer and stored in the key vault or generated using the Azure key vault's APIs). Customer-managed keys enables a customer to encrypt the data with an Azure Key Vault key that is created and owned by them. Also, the customer has full control and responsibility for the key lifecycle, including rotation and management. Hence, it is recommended to use customer-managed keys to encrypt the container registries.

If access to container registries is not restricted by IP/firewall rule, then any attacker will be able to gain access to the data present in the registry from malicious IP addresses or domains without getting detected. Along with this, the container registry will also be susceptible to other network attacks like DDoS, Eavesdropping, Jamming, etc.

Remediation of this control can be performed for the Premium container registry service tier. If the access to private endpoints, selected subnets, or IP addresses is restricted then the Security Center will not be able to perform image vulnerability scanning (by Azure Defender) of the images in the container registry. Also, instances of certain Azure services including Azure DevOps Services, Web Apps, and Azure Container Instances will not be able to access a network-restricted container registry.

An Azure container registry by default accepts connections over the internet from hosts on any network. To protect the container registries from potential threats, it must be ensured that access is restricted to only specific public IP addresses or address ranges by configuring the IP/firewall rule of the container registry.

Note: Networking settings (IP access rule and service endpoint) can be configured only for premium container registries

If private links are not configured for container registries, then any attacker will be able to gain access to the container registry's content from malicious public IP address or domain, without getting detected. Along with this, the container registry will also be susceptible to other network attacks like DDoS, Eavesdropping, Jamming, etc.

Remediation of this control can be performed for the Premium container registry service tier. If the access to private endpoints, selected subnets, or IP addresses is restricted then the Security Center will not be able to perform image vulnerability scanning (by Azure Defender) of the images in the container registry. Also, instances of certain Azure services including Azure DevOps Services, Web Apps, and Azure Container Instances will not be able to access a network-restricted container registry.

Access to the container registry can be restricted by assigning virtual network private IP addresses to the registry endpoints and using Azure Private Link. Network traffic between the clients on the virtual network and the registry's private endpoints traverses the virtual network and a private link on the Microsoft backbone network, eliminating exposure from the public internet. By mapping private endpoints to the container registries instead of the entire service, the container registry's content will also be protected against data leakage risks.
If secure connections are not enabled for Redis Cache, then a malicious user within the network path will be able to gain unauthorized access to the data through Man-in-the-Middle attack.

Remediation of this control will ensure that only secure connections can access the the Redis Cache. However, before enabling access only via SSL for the Redis Cache, it must be ensured that all clients consuming the Redis instance have trusted certificate configured.

Only secure connections via SSL should be able to access the Redis Cache. Use of secure connections ensures authentication between the server and the service and protects data in transit from network layer attacks such as man-in-the-middle, eavesdropping, and session-hijacking.

If Azure Cache for Redis is not configured inside a virtual network, then it exposes the service to internet users. A malicious user can attempt credential bruteforce to gain unauthorized access to the cached data.

Remediation of this control will ensure that the Azure Cache for Redis is not accessible publicly. However, the Network Security Groups(NSGs) and other network rules must be configured carefully, such that all the trusted client's network traffic is allowed to reach the Azure Cache for Redis instance.

Azure virtual network deployment provides enhanced security and isolation for the Azure Cache for Redis, along with subnets, access control policies, and other features to further restrict access. When an Azure Cache for Redis instance is configured with a virtual network, it is not publicly addressable and can only be accessed from virtual machines and applications within the virtual network.

If HTTP is used for accessing the function app, then data will be transmitted in plain text thereby increasing the chances for an attacker to steal the sensitive information via network layer attacks such as man-in-the-middle, eavesdropping, etc.

Remediation of this control will ensure that only secure connections can access the function app. However, before enabling only HTTPS access for the function app, it must be ensured that there isn't any existing resource that can only access the function app over HTTP.

An Azure Function App is a collection of Azure functions (cloud service available on-demand that helps in building the web APIs, responding to the database changes, processing IoT streams, managing message queues, etc) that are grouped together as a logical unit, and are helpful in making the management, deployment, scaling, and sharing of resources easier. A client can connect to the function endpoints by using both HTTP (data is not encrypted and is transmitted in plain text) or HTTPS (data is encrypted and transmitted securely via SSL/TLS protocols). HTTPS protects the communication between the client and server from being intercepted and tampered with by attackers. This provides confidentiality, integrity and authentication.
If remote debugging is enabled on the function app, then the inbound ports used for debugging the function app can be used as an entry point by an attacker to access and exploit all the resources.
Remediation of this control will turn off remote debugging for the function app, and user will not be able to remotely debug any issue that arises in any function after deployment.

Remote Debugging connects two of Microsoft's most powerful technologies, the Azure cloud and Visual Studio. It allows user to connect to the deployed website and gain full control. the user can set breakpoints, manipulate memory directly, step through code and even change code path. To facilitate this feature the server has to open certain inbound ports for the Visual Studio remote debugger within the Microsoft Azure App Services web applications configuration. Other than the risks of changing code in the production environment, these ports can also prove to be an entry point for an attacker to try to gain control of the live application. Implementing the principle of least privilege by closing the access to these inbound ports will help in significantly reducing the possibility of a security breach.

If Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS) allows every resource to access function app, then all the CORS request made to the function app will pass the evaluation criteria i.e. '*'. This setting is equivalent to disabling CORS and would make the function app vulnerable to scripting attacks.

Remediation of this control will ensure that the resources from specified domains are allowed to access the function apps, while remediating the user must ensure that none of the domains are missed in the configuration, as it will result in inaccessibility of the function app to the missed domain's resources.

CORS (Cross-Origin Resource Sharing) is an HTTP feature that enables a function app running under one domain to access resources in another domain. All resources implement a security restriction known as same-origin policy that prevents a web page from calling APIs in a different domain; CORS provides a secure way to allow one domain (the origin domain) to call APIs in another domain. CORS acts as a defence against scripting attacks. It should be configured to restrict function app's access to trusted resources only. Configuring CORS rule with '*' is as good as disabling CORS as this configuration will pass all the CORS request made to access the function app. Allowing all resources to access the function app will enable all the untrusted users to gain access to the data and services being managed by the function app.

FTP is a non-secure way to transfer data. When a file is sent using this protocol, the data, username, password and other sensitive informations are shared in plain text, which means a hacker can access this information with little to no effort. Hence, it is recommended to use FTPS (secured FTP) instead of FTP.

Remediation of this control should be performed after ensuring that all the FTP servers have SSL/TLS protocol support available, so that none of the data transmissions with the already existing FTP client gets disturbed.

FTPS (Secure FTP) is used to enhance security for the function apps as it adds an extra layer of security to the FTP protocol, and helps in complying with the industry standards and regulations such as PCI DSS, HIPAA. With FTP, the transmission of data between the function app and the FTP client is unencrypted, leaving the data vulnerable to being intercepted and read.  Enforcing FTPS-only access for the Azure App Services applications, can guarantee that the encrypted traffic between the function app and the FTP clients cannot be decrypted by malicious actors in case they are able to intercept packets sent across the FTP connection. Hence, it must be ensured that the function apps enforce FTPS-only access to encrypt FTP traffic.

If TLS is not updated to the latest version, then all the bugs related to the older version will persist and will not get patched. Also, the older TLS version might result in the future issues with several third party service providers that have restricted access to connections via older TLS versions.
Remediation of this control will upgrade TLS to the latest version, which must be done with caution and it must be ensured that the existing functionalities do not get impacted.

Transport Layer Security (TLS) is a protocol that provides privacy and data integrity between two communicating applications. TLS should be updated to the latest version to comply with the security standards and regulations such as PCI DSS, HIPAA, etc.

If managed identity is not used then the developers will have to store the credentials in the code so that the users can authenticate and access different cloud services, which will increase the overhead of managing and securing the credentials and secrets.

It is advised to proceed with caution while creating managed identities as if the subscription is to be moved or transferred to another directory, then the managed identities linked to it will not get updated and will have to be re-assigned to the necessary resources.

A managed identity is used for enhancing the authentication security of the cloud services. In Azure, the managed identities eliminate the need for developers to have to manage credentials by providing an identity for the Azure resource in Azure AD and using it to obtain Azure Active Directory (Azure AD) tokens. These tokens can be used for accessing other resources that are registered with the Azure AD, such as Azure Key Vault. The permission level of these managed identities can be changed using Azure RBAC(Role Based Access Control).

If the service-managed key is used instead of a customer-managed key for encrypting the Azure Cosmos DB account then the key creation, storage, rotation, and lifecycle will all be managed by Microsoft. In an Azure Cosmos DB account, by default, the data is encrypted at rest with service-managed keys (Transparent to the application and are managed by Microsoft), but customer-managed keys (Customer controls keys via Azure key vault) are commonly required to meet regulatory compliance standards. Customer-managed keys enables a customer to encrypt the data with an Azure key vault key that is created and owned by them. Also, the customer has full control and responsibility for the key lifecycle, including rotation and management. Hence, it is recommended to use customer-managed keys to manage the encryption at rest of the Azure Cosmos DB data.

If the firewall rules are not configured for the Azure Cosmos DB accounts, then by default, it will accept requests from any source (including the public internet). This would compromise the confidentiality of the Azure Cosmos DB accounts as any unauthorized user can brute-force into these accounts and gain access to the information stored in them.

Remediation of this control will configure the firewall rules for the Azure Cosmos DB acconts, which would result in the denial of all the requests made to the Azure Cosmos DB account from any unallowed IP address/range. Also, the browsing of Azure Cosmos DB resources from the portal will be blocked.

Azure Cosmos DB accounts should be configured to deny access to traffic from all unauthorized networks, including the public Internet. The access to the Azure Cosmos DB accounts should be granted only to specific Azure virtual networks that allows a secure network boundary for specific applications, or to public IP addresses/IP address ranges which can enable connections from trusted Internet services and on-premises networks. Once the firewall rules are properly configured, only clients and applications from allowed networks and/or IPs can access the Azure Cosmos DB account resources.

Note: Making changes to the network firewall rules can impact the applications' ability to connect to the Cosmos DB account. Make sure to grant access to any trusted service or network using network rules or IP addresses/ranges before configuring the firewall default rule to deny access.

Remediation of this control cannot be performed on an already provisioned server. Hence, if it is required to move the backup storage from locally redundant storage to geo-redundant storage, then the only supported option is to create a new Azure Database for MariaDB and migrate the data using dump and restore. The overall migration and selecting geo-redundant option during new database creation would incur additonal costs as compared to when local-redundant option is selected.

Backup and restore are an essential part of a business continuity strategy because it protects the data from accidental corruption or deletion. Azure Database for MariaDB allows us to set the backup and restore option for the database server to either geo-redundant or locally redundant storage. Setting the backup and restore option to geo-redundant backup storage will allow the data to be stored not only within the region in which the server is hosted, but also will replicate it to a paired region to provide recovery options in case of a region failure. Also, the configuration of locally redundant or geo-redundant storage for backup is only allowed at the time of creation of server.

If the private endpoint is not enabled for Azure Database for MariaDB, then the only way to access the resources is through the public endpoint. This will expose the server to attacks such as man-in-the-middle, credential bruteforce, etc. as it will be accessible over the internet.

Remediation of this control will ensure that only the configured resources in Azure are able to communicate using IP of the server's private endpoint, hence it must be ensured that all the Azure resources dependent on the Azure Database for MariaDB are configured to be able to access the database server through this private endpoint.

Private endpoint connections enforce secure communication by enabling private connectivity to Azure Database for MariaDB. It is recommended to configure a private endpoint connection for Azure Database for MariaDB, to enable access to traffic coming only from known networks and prevent access from all other IP addresses, including within Azure.

If public network access to Azure Database for MariaDB is enabled, then the accessibility of the database will be increased thereby exposing the server to attacks such as man-in-the-middle, credentials bruteforce, etc.

Remediation of this control will deny any public IP address from accessing the Azure Database for MariaDB. The only way to access the database will be through the private endpoint, hence public network access must be disabled cautiously.

The public network access to Azure Database for MariaDB should be disabled, this will improve security and will ensure that the data is only accessible from a private endpoint. Setting this configuration will strictly disable access from any public address space outside of Azure IP range, and will deny all logins that match IP or virtual network-based firewall rules.

If a Web Application Firewall is not enabled on an Application Gateway, then a malicious internet user or a bot can target the backend application with exploits for known vulnerabilities. A Web Application Firewall (WAF) should be enabled for Application Gateway to provide centralized protection of the web applications from common exploits and vulnerabilities such as SQL injections, Cross-Site Scripting, local and remote file executions. WAF, if enabled will also restrict access to the web applications by countries, IP address ranges, and other http(s) parameters via custom rules.

If HTTP is used with the API App for integrating with the cloud applications, then data will be transmitted in plain text thereby increasing the chances for an attacker to steal the sensitive information via network layer attacks such as man-in-the-middle, eavesdropping, etc.

Remediation of this control will ensure that only secure connections can access the API App. However, before enabling only HTTPS access for the API App, it must be ensured that there isn't any existing resource that can only access the API App over HTTP.

API Apps are the Azure App Service that offers a rich platform and ecosystem for building, consuming, and distributing APIs in the cloud and on-premises. A client can connect to the cloud applications such as Office 365, SalesForce, Dynamics, OneDrive, Box, DropBox, Twilio, Twitter, Facebook, Marketo, etc via the API App by using both HTTP (data is not encrypted and is transmitted in plain text) or HTTPS (data is encrypted and transmitted securely via SSL/TLS protocols). It is recommended to use HTTPS, as it will protect the data in transit from being intercepted and tampered with by attackers.

If managed identity is not used then the developers will have to store the credentials in the code so that the users can authenticate and access different cloud services, which will increase the overhead of managing and securing the credentials and secrets.
If the subscription is to be moved or transferred to another directory, then the managed identities linked to it will not get updated and will have to be re-assigned to the necessary resources.

A managed identity is used for enhancing the authentication security of the cloud services. In Azure, the managed identities eliminate the need for developers to have to manage credentials by providing an identity for the Azure resource (API App) in Azure AD and using it to obtain Azure Active Directory (Azure AD) tokens. These tokens can be used for accessing other resources that are registered with the Azure AD, such as Azure Key Vault. The permission level of these managed identities can be changed using Azure RBAC(Role Based Access Control).

FTP is a non-secure way to transfer data. When a file is sent using this protocol, the data, username, password and other sensitive informations are shared in plain text, which means a hacker can access this information with little to no effort. Hence, it is recommended to use FTPS(secured FTP) instead of FTP.

Remediation of this control should be performed after ensuring that all the FTP servers have SSL/TLS protocol support available, so that none of the data transmissions with the already existing FTP client gets disturbed.

FTPS (Secure FTP) is used to enhance security for the API Apps in Azure, by adding an extra layer of security to the FTP protocol, and thereby helping in complying with the industry standards and regulations such as PCI-DSS, HIPAA. With FTP, the transmission of data between the API App and the FTP client is unencrypted, leaving the data vulnerable to being intercepted and read. Enforcing FTPS-only access for the Azure App Services applications, can guarantee that the encrypted traffic between the API App servers and the FTP clients cannot be decrypted by malicious actors in case they are able to intercept packets sent across the FTP connection. Hence, it must be ensured that the Azure App Services API Apps enforce FTPS-only access to encrypt FTP traffic.

Without enabling diagnostic logs for apps in App Service, one will not be able to diagnose the runtime failures related to the applications which could have been detected with the help of generated logs.
Remediating this control enables logging for the apps in App Service, which may incur additional costs to store or process diagnostic log data.

An App Service is a http-based service for developing and hosting web applications, REST APIs, and mobile back ends in any programming language. It offers auto-scaling and high availability, supports both Windows and Linux, and enables automated deployments from GitHub, Azure DevOps, or any Git repo. The Diagnostic Logs are logs emitted by a resource and provide insight into the operation of that resource. By enabling diagnostic logs, one can record and store information about the runtime data and events which would help in troubleshooting the application. Thus, it is recommended to enable logging for the App Service.

If Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS) allows every resource to access the API App, then all the CORS request made to the API App will pass the evaluation criteria i.e. '*'. This setting is equivalent to disabling CORS and would make the application vulnerable to scripting attacks.

Remediation of this control will ensure that the resources from specified domains are allowed to access the API apps, while remediating the user must ensure that none of the domains are missed in the configuration, as it will result in inaccessibility of the API App to the missed domain's resources.

CORS (Cross-Origin Resource Sharing) is an HTTP feature that enables an API App running under one domain to access resources in another domain. All resources implement a security restriction known as same-origin policy that prevents an App Service from calling APIs in a different domain; CORS provides a secure way to allow one domain (the origin domain) to call APIs in another domain. CORS acts as a defence against scripting attacks. It should be configured to restrict API App's access to trusted resources only. Configuring CORS rule with '*' is as good as disabling CORS as this configuration will pass all the CORS request made to access the API app. Allowing all resources to access the API App will enable all the untrusted users to gain access to the data and services being managed by the API App.
If remote debugging is enabled on the API App, then the inbound ports used for debugging the API App can be used as an entry point by an attacker to access and exploit all the resources.
Remediation of this control will turn off remote debugging for the API App, and user will not be able to remotely debug any issue that arises in any API App after deployment.

Remote Debugging connects two of Microsoft's most powerful technologies, the Azure cloud and Visual Studio. It allows user to connect to the deployed website and gain full control. the user can set breakpoints, manipulate memory directly, step through code and even change code path. To facilitate this feature the server has to open certain inbound ports for the Visual Studio remote debugger within the Microsoft Azure App Services API App configuration. Other than the risks of changing code in the production environment, these ports can also prove to be an entry point for an attacker to try to gain control of the live application. Implementing the principle of least privilege by closing the access to these inbound ports will help in significantly reducing the possibility of a security breach.

If TLS is not updated to the latest version, then all the bugs related to the older version will persist and will not get patched. Remediation of this control will upgrade TLS to the latest version, which must be done with caution and it must be ensured that the existing users are not refrained from accessing the API App.

Transport Layer Security (TLS) is a protocol that provides privacy and data integrity between two communicating applications. TLS helps in validating the client certificate and authenticating the requests made to the API App by the client over HTTPS. Hence, it is recommended to use the latest version of TLS to comply with the regulatory standards such as PCI-DSS, HIPAA, etc.

NSGs when associated with the subnets helps in restricting access by applying ACL rules to all the VM instances and integrated services in that subnet, thereby protecting the subnets from potential attacks such as DDoS, credentials bruteforce, Man-in-the-Middle attack, etc.

Network traffic between the clients on the virtual network and the event grid topic's private endpoints traverses the virtual network and a private link on the Microsoft backbone network, eliminating exposure from the public internet. By mapping private endpoints to the event grid topic instead of the entire service, the content will also be protected against data leakage risks.

Azure Data Lake Store is a cloud platform that provides scalable, cost-effective storage for big data analytics. The Diagnostic Logs in Azure are the logs emitted by a resource and provide an insight into the operation of that resource. Enabling diagnostic logging for Azure Data Lake Store helps in collecting the access audit trails, that provide information about the list of users that accessed the data, frequency of accessing the data, how much data is stored in the account, etc.

Without a vulnerability assessment solution installed, a number of open vulnerabilities like remote cloud execution (an action which involves an attacker executing code remotely using system vulnerabilities) can go undetected which can double up as openings for an attacker to gain access to the operations of a SQL managedinstances remotely and make breaking changes.

Remediation of this control enables a built-in vulnerability assessment solution and also provides other thrid party vulnerability assessment scanners, the usage of which may require licensing and incur additional charges.

A core component of every cyber risk and security program is the identification and analysis of vulnerabilities. The vulnerability assessment scanner works by deploying various assessment extensions on the SQL managed instance, then it gathers information by collecting artifacts and sending them to the cloud services, which conducts the vulnerability assessments over it and sends its findings to Security Center. Thereby, helping in the discovery, tracking and remediation of potential vulnerabilities. Hence, it is recommended to install a vulnerability assessment solution (included with Azure Defender) to enable a best of breed vulnerability assessment solution on the SQL managed instances.

If Azure Defender for SQL is not enabled on the SQL managed instances then we will not be able to detect anomalous database access patterns and mitigate potential database vulnerabilities such as SQL injection, password bruteforce attacks, etc.
If Azure Defender is enabled for protecting all the SQL databases on the SQL managed instance, then additional charges will be incurred.

Azure Defender for SQL is a unified package that provides advanced SQL security capabilities.  It includes functionality for surfacing and mitigating potential database vulnerabilities, detecting anomalous activities that could indicate a threat to the database, and discovering and classifying sensitive data.
Important: The cost of Azure Defender is aligned with Azure Security Center standard tier pricing per managed instance. You are thus paying only once for protecting all databases on the managed instance with Azure Defender.
(Related policy: Advanced data security should be enabled on SQL Managed Instance)

If the platform-managed key is used instead of a customer-managed key for encrypting the SQL managed instances then the key creation, storage, rotation, and lifecycle will all be managed by Microsoft. This key management policy may not be in adherence to the global/state regulatory requirements. Additionally, the platform-managed keys does not provide audit logs as well as fine grained controls over the key access, thereby any misuse of this key may go unnoticed.

Remediation of this control will ensure that customer-managed keys are used for encrypting the SQL managed instance in Azure, but both the Key-Vault and the key used for encryption must not get deleted or expired, as this will make the database inaccessible.

Implementing Transparent Data Encryption (TDE) with customer-managed key enables Bring Your Own Key (BYOK) scenario for data protection at rest, and allows organizations to implement separation of duties in the management of keys and data. With customer-managed transparent data encryption the data is encrypted with a customer-managed asymmetric key (TDE protector) stored in the customer-owned Azure Key Vault. Also, the customer is responsible for and in a full control of the key lifecycle management (key creation, upload, rotation, deletion), key usage permissions, and auditing of operations on keys.
Vulnerability assessment can discover, track, and help you remediate potential database vulnerabilities.

API Management service, if not deployed inside a virtual network will make it accessible over the internet. The attackers will be able to access these services through the use of malicious IP addresses or public endpoints without being detected.

Remediation of this control will ensure that the API Management service is not accessible publicly. However, while deploying an API Management service to a Resource Manager virtual network, the service must be in a dedicated subnet that contains no other resources except for instances of the API Management service. If an attempt is made to deploy an Azure API Management service to a Resource Manager virtual network subnet that contains other resources, the deployment will fail.

API Management services are used for creating consistent and modern API gateways for existing back-end services. The virtual network deployment of the API Management services provides enhanced security, isolation and allows us to place these services in a non-internet routable network to which the access can be controlled. These networks can then be connected to the on-premises networks using various VPN technologies, which enables access to the backend services within the network and/or on-premises. The developer portal and API gateway, can be configured to be accessible either from the Internet or only within the virtual network.

If the Microsoft-managed key is used instead of a customer-managed key for encrypting the data in the Cognitive Services, then the key's creation, storage, rotation, and lifecycle will all be managed by Microsoft. This key management policy may not be in adherence to the global/state regulatory requirements. Additionally, the Microsoft-managed keys does not provide audit logs as well as fine grained controls over the key access, thereby any misuse of this key may go unnoticed.

Remediation of this control will ensure that customer-managed keys are used for encrypting the data in the Cognitive Services account, but both the Key-Vault and the key used for encryption must not get deleted or expired, as this will make the Cognitive Services account inaccessible.

Customer-managed keys (created by a customer and stored in the key vault or generated using the Azure key vault's APIs) should be used to manage the encryption at rest of the Cognitive Services account. By default, the data is encrypted at rest with service-managed keys (transparent to the application and are managed by Microsoft), but customer-managed keys are commonly required to meet regulatory compliance standards. Customer-managed keys enables a customer to encrypt the data stored in Cognitive Services with an Azure Key Vault key that is created and owned by them. Also, the customer has full control and responsibility for the key lifecycle, including rotation and management.

If access to Cognitive Services account is not restricted by the virtual network rules, then any attacker will be able to gain access to the data present in these accounts from malicious IP addresses or domains without getting detected. This would thereby make the Cognitive Services accounts susceptible to other network layer attacks such as DDoS, Eavesdropping, etc.

If the access to the Cognitive Services account is restricted by configuring the virtual network rules, then any incoming request other than the one originating from any service that is operating within an Azure virtual network or an allowed IP address, will be blocked. Hence, it must be exercised cautiously so that all the trusted resources and services are able to access the data present in the Cognitive Services accounts.

Network access to Cognitive Services accounts should be restricted by configuring network rules so that only applications from allowed networks are able to access the Cognitive Services account. To allow connections from specific internet or on-premises clients, access can be granted to traffic from specific Azure virtual networks or to public internet IP address ranges.

If public network access to the Cognitive Services account is enabled, then the accessibility of these accounts will increase. This would thereby expose the Cognitive Services accounts to several network attacks such as DDoS, Eavesdropping, etc.

Remediation of this control will deny any public IP address from accessing the Cognitive Services accounts. The only way to access these accounts will be through the private endpoint, hence public network access must be disabled cautiously.

The public network access to Cognitive Services accounts should be disabled to ensure that the data stored in these accounts is accessible only via private endpoints. Disabling public access will decrease the accessibility of the data, and thereby enhance its security by making it inaccessible over the internet. Hence, as a best security practice, the public network access to the Cognitive Services account should be disabled.

Without enabling data encryption for the Cognitive Services account, all the information present in these accounts will be stored in plain-text form. Hence, in case of a compromise, an attacker will have complete access to the data stored in these accounts and use it for any unauthorized purpose.

Remediation of this control will ensure that any new data stored in the Cognitive Services account is encrypted, also, all the existing files will be retroactively encrypted by a background encryption process.

Cognitive Services account with storage, should enable data encryption with either Customer managed or Microsoft managed key.  By default, every subscription uses Microsoft managed encryption keys, but if the pricing tier supports Customer managed keys, then a customer can select between the encryption types for encrypting the Cognitive Services account.

Note: In case of Customer managed key both Soft Delete and Do Not Purge properties on the key vault must be enabled, also, RSA keys of size 2048 must be used for encryption.

If the private endpoint is not enabled for Machine Learning workspaces in Azure, then the only way to access this resource would be through the public endpoint. This will expose the server to attacks such as man-in-the-middle, credential bruteforce, etc. as it will be accessible over the internet.

Remediation of this control will ensure that only the configured resources in Azure are able to communicate using the private endpoint, hence it must be ensured that all the Azure resources dependent on the Machine Learning workspaces are configured to be able to access it through this private endpoint.

In Azure, private endpoints helps in connecting the virtual network to the Azure services without the public IP address at the source or destination. By configuring the private endpoints for the Machine Learning workspace, the connectivity between the consumer and services are handled over the Azure backbone network. It is recommended to configure a private endpoint connection for Machine Learning workspaces in Azure, to enable access to traffic coming only from known networks and prevent access from all other IP addresses.

Additionally, the Microsoft-managed keys does not provide audit logs as well as fine grained controls over the key access, thereby any misuse of this key may go unnoticed.

Remediation of this control will ensure that customer-managed keys are used for encrypting the Machine Learning workspaces. The Key Vault must be in the same region as that of the workspace, else the deployment will fail.

Customer-managed keys (created by a customer and stored in the key vault or generated using the Azure key vault's APIs) should be used to manage the encryption at rest of the data stored in Machine Learning workspace. By default, the data is encrypted at rest with service-managed keys (transparent to the application and are managed by Microsoft), but customer-managed keys are commonly required to meet regulatory compliance standards. Customer-managed keys enables a customer to encrypt the data with an Azure Key Vault key that is created and owned by them. Also, the customer has full control and responsibility for the key lifecycle, including rotation and management.

Without installing Log Analytics agent, it will not be possible to collect logs and performance data from Azure Arc machines and send it to a Log Analytics workspace to take advantage of features supported by Azure Monitor Logs such as log queries where the logs can be analyzed together using a sophisticated query language that's capable of quickly analyzing millions of records, which can bring out critical patterns (like resource usage insights, protocol failures, network outages etc) in your monitoring data with the help of which the organization can solve detected problems as quickly as possible or prevent them before they happen.
Remediating this control installs Log Analytics agent, which will not have any impact, however the collected data cannot be sent to the Azure Monitor Metrics, Azure Storage, or Azure Event Hubs.

The Log Analytics agent collects monitoring data from the guest operating system and workloads of virtual machines in Azure, other cloud providers, and on-premises and sends that data into a Log Analytics workspace. It is used by Azure Monitor, Azure Security Center, and Azure Sentinel, among other Azure management solutions. Security Center uses the Log Analytics agent (also known as Microsoft Monitoring Agent (MMA)) to collect security events from the Azure Arc machines.
If auditing is not enabled for SQL servers then any activity being performed by an unauthorized user on the SQL server will go undetected, as no audit logs will be generated to re-trace the activity.

Remediation of this control will ensure that the audit logs are generated for the SQL server, but during very high activity, or high network load, SQL database in Azure will allow operations to proceed and may not record some audited events.

Auditing for SQL servers in Azure helps in tracking the activities across all databases on the server and writing them to an audit log in the Azure storage account, Log Analytics workspace, or Event Hubs. This would help in maintaining the regulatory compliance and gaining insight into the discrepancies and anomalies that could indicate business concerns or suspected security violations.

Protect your subnet from potential threats by restricting access to it with a network security group (NSG). NSGs contain a list of Access Control List (ACL) rules that allow or deny network traffic to your subnet. When an NSG is associated with a subnet, the ACL rules apply to all the VM instances and integrated services in that subnet, but don't apply to internal traffic inside the subnet. To secure resources in the same subnet from one another, enable NSG directly on the resources as well.
Note that the following subnet types will be listed as not applicable: GatewaySubnet, AzureFirewallSubnet, AzureBastionSubnet.
